I think you need to be aware that all domain registrations have the potential to have a web site, email or even FTP and Gopher servers, to step back about 30 years. These are all just protocols that require infrastructure and some registration in DNS.

Gandi offer domains specifically for email hosting and can be accessed for such through the Thunderbird new account wizard or check here shop.gandi.net/en/domain/suggest? as a registrar for the .name space, you could transfer your existing domain registrations there.

Can you tell me who your existing registrar is in the .name domain (the actual domain name would be good as well).
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Not really asking you to resolve the dot name domain issue. But for completeness will outline its structure and function. dot name has been around for 20years. Its structure is firstname dot familyname dot name, and includes email forwarding to a similar structure, ie, firstname @ familyname dot name.

The gmail authentication operates on the part to the right of the @. familyname dot name. Clearly using smith, jones, Mohamed, etc, many family names have millions of firstnames, ie millions of 3rd level (only the first one to register gets the unique 3rd level domain, joe or joan, etc). Hence, no individual can own the second level, and thus no individual can verify their email because they don't own the second level domain, no DNS, etc. So all dot name domain client who use the forwarding will come a cropper.

Verisign, the register for dot name, are playing hardball, saying the forwarding is only used for replies, but gmail, and I suspect, many others will follow their lead, are comparing incoming and outgoing to trap scammers, ie, those pretending to be someone they are not.

content:
Hello Simon,

2FA on the one hand and OpenPGP and S/MIME on the other hand are not related. In fact, the two are solutions for different problems.

2FA ensures that anybody who wants to login to your email account or who wants to connect to it using an email client like Thunderbird must provide a second factor (the 2F in 2FA). It is not enough to just know your username or e-mail address and your password. A second factor is required in addition to the password, which would be the first factor. An important characteristic of this second factor is that it is not some fixed value like your password (something you know). The second factor is often linked to you as a person (think of your fingerprint or your face, something you are) or it is something that is valid only for a limited time and can only be generated by a special device or tool (something you own). Both types require you to be present while connecting to your email account. You must present your fingerprint or your face or you must read the currently valid code from the special device. It is difficult to automate these actions. Therefore email clients like thunderbird usually don't support 2FA. Usually you don't want to present the second factor every time you open your email client.

OpenPGP and S/MIME are ways to encrypt email between the sender and the receiver. The sender and the receiver agree on a shared secret (usually using something called public-key cryptography). The sender then encrypts the email on his device using this secret. Only then does he send the email to the receiver. The receiver then uses the secret to decrypt the email on his device. During the whole way the email takes from sender to receiver it is encryped. This is even true while it is sitting on some email server, waiting for it to be delivered. Nobody except the sender and the receiver are able to ever decrypt the message.

You can combine 2FA and OpenPGP and S/MIME. You can use the former the make it impossible to access your email account for some attacker who managed to steal your password. You can use the later to make sure that nobody can read an email other the the receiver you want to be able to read it.

Thunderbird supports OpenPGP and S/MIME out of the box. I am not aware of any way to use 2FA.
creator: user75936209463636981919672261829024851314

Is the scenario that someone might get on your computer and start Thunderbird?

You can prevent Thunderbird from immediately/automatically connecting to your mailbox to send/receive mail by creating a Primary Password: Protect your Thunderbird passwords with a Primary Password. (Important: do not forget this password!)

However, that won't prevent them from starting Thunderbird, canceling the password prompt, and seeing all previously sent/received messages (similar to working offline).

I don't know whether there is any built-in or add-on method of requiring a credential to view previously sent/received messages saved in Thunderbird.

content:
re :however in the setting it still shows my old Spectrum PW and I can't change it.

Did you do this:

  • Settings > Privacy & Security'
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords' button
  • Click on 'Show Passwords' button

For a pop account there should be two lines - mailbox://account and smtp://account

  • Right click on mailbox line and select 'Edit Password'
  • Completely clear all contents
  • Type in new password
  • Repeat for the smtp line.


I'm wondering if you have got the correct settings for the Pop accounts. It's possible you set up the account as a pop account but recently got bad advise on server settings. So let's be certain this is correct.

Please post the following information:

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Section'
  • Post an image showing everything in that section.

The next section is for information in future. But do not start adding any more accounts until we have checked out the original one which should already be using the Global Inbox.

re : I can't find anyway to associate my email address with the original INBOX that Thunderbird set up, I don't want to have 2 inboxes..

All Pop accounts get auto created as their own account with their own set of folders. You saw this when you created the new pop account - assuming it is a new pop account. Thunderbird does not auto set up deferred accounts - aka also known as 'Global Inbox' This is something you would have had to do when you created the account. Only Pop accounts can use Global Inbox.

In Account Settings

  • Select 'Server Settings' for the account:
  • click on 'Advanced' button

To set up as a deferred account using Global Inbox:

  • Select 'Inbox for different account'
  • Select 'Global Inbox (Local Folders)'
  • Select checkbox 'Include this server when getting new mail'
  • Click on 'OK'

Then check the following are all pointing to use 'Local Folders' account.

  • Select 'Copies & Folders'
  • For each - Sent - Archives - Drafts - Templates
  • Set all to use correct folder on 'Local Folders'
  • Select 'Junk Settings'
  • Select 'Move new junk messages to'
  • Select 'Junk folder on and choose 'Local Folders'

Then restart Thunderbird.

content:
If 'Local Folders' account only ever had emails you had copied or moved from an imap account into 'Local Folders' mail account, then the reason you cannot use 'Write' or 'Get Messages' is because you do not have any mail accounts.

It would fully explain why you have a problem. Please send image of Account Settings before you create an account.

Suggest you create an Imap mail account - if you want an Imap setup. Imap accounts will have their own set of folders because all the folders in an imap account synchronise with the folders on the server. Imap accounts can only display whatever is on the server. They are basically one and the same set of folders. Imap accounts should never be regarded as independent of server because they can only display whatever is on server. You subscribe to see server folders in an imap account.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
So, originally you had a Pop account. It download all emails into the 'Local Folders' account. You never saw it as a separate pop account in Folder Pane as all emails got downloaded into the 'Local Folders' mail account. In other words, that original Pop account was set up as a deferred account pointing it to use Global Inbox 'Local Folders'.

Then you got advise from Spectrum to get rid of the Pop account and use an Imap account. So, you deleted the Pop account meaning the 'Local Folders' mail account remained as it was but was no longer being used as an Inbox.

Then you created the imap account - hmastro Imap accounts cannot use 'Local Folders' mail account. Imap account has it's own set of folders because it has to synchronise with server.

This meant you now had a mail account so you could Get Messages and Write. then you deleted the Imap account. So you are back to square one with no mail account.

Next Step Do you want to set up a Pop account which uses the 'Local Folders' account like before OR do you want to now use an Imap account which has it's own set of folders?

creator: quiltjunkie2002

content:
When you create a new mail account

  • File > New > Exisitng Mail Account

You enter name, email address and password Select checkbox to remember password click on 'continue'. Thunderbird will auto try to locate setting, but by default it looks for Imap. So, you can now see what Thunderbird has located at this point you need to select the 'Protocol' = 'Pop' option and select 'Retest'. Thunderbird will the check for server settings. If there is still an issue, you can use the 'Configure manually' option. I've posted the server settings for Pop below. In the past many users had 'User name' as first part of email address, but in recent years and it is mentioned on their website - you need to enter the full email address.

You will need the following: POP

  • The incoming mail server: mail.twc.com
  • Incoming server port:110.
  • Connection Security:None
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • User name : full email address
  • Outgoing mail server (SMTP): mail.twc.com
  • Outgoing server port: 587.
  • Connection Security:None but is worth trying STARTTLS first.
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • User name : full email address


Once account is created, do not download anything. First - Go into the Account Settings: In Account Settings

  • Select 'Server Settings' for the Pop account:
  • click on 'Advanced' button

To set up as a deferred account using Global Inbox:

  • Select 'Inbox for different account'
  • Select 'Global Inbox (Local Folders)'
  • Select checkbox 'Include this server when getting new mail'
  • Click on 'OK'

Then check the following are all pointing to use 'Local Folders' account.

  • Select 'Copies & Folders'
  • For each - Sent - Archives - Drafts - Templates
  • Set all to use correct folder on 'Local Folders'
  • Select 'Junk Settings'
  • Select 'Move new junk messages to'
  • Select 'Junk folder on and choose 'Local Folders'

Then restart Thunderbird immediately. This is important.
creator: Toad-Hall

Can I get that back? Thanks so much for your help, you are dealing with a 75 year old that really does only do fair on computers, but I do donate every once in a while. Thanks again.
creator: ctaylorpro48

content: You can use your Gmail addressbook in thunderbird. Here are the basic steps: - click to addressbook - click new addressbook and from there, select 'add carddav addressbook - on next box, enter gmail.com and click next. Google will pop up to prompt you for your id and password. Once done, your online addressbook will be added
creator: davidsk

Thanks much, sorry to be a pain, but I have a BUNCH of address to bring over.
creator: ctaylorpro48

content: Ok. I attached a screenshot. - click to addressbook - one entry on menu is 'New Address Book' - click that and a drop down menu appears with an option for a carddav addressbook - click that and on new pane, type in a descriptive name for the address book in top line and on second line, enter gmail.com - google will produce a pop up for you to enter your gmail credentials. - once done, it enters location for the addressbook that you can now use in Thunderbird.

content: One option might be to take to a computer repair shop to extract the files. Another might be to log onto your gmail account and check the contacts. If there are email addresses there, then something very unusual happened with setting it up with thunderbird. Another option there, assuming you have email addresses there, is to export from gmail. A website that explains the steps is at https://www.howtogeek.com/709323/how-to-export-contacts-in-gmail/ If you go this route and download a CSV file, it can be imported to thunderbird at tools>import>import from a file.

I do appreciate you trying to help this old fart!!

content:
That is great news. I was glad to assist. Be sure to backup. I do it regularly. Best way for me is the simple way: - exit Thunderbird - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to a USB stick - to restore: 

  1. install thunderbird, if necessary   2. copy from USB stick to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming  (that will prompt for overwrite. Allow.)
creator: davidsk

content:
Goodmorning Wayne Mery,

Thanks very much for your reply! I am sorry to tell you that all the efforts I made did not help. I made it clear that Thunderbird almost never gave problems so far. The issues started when the new version 115 Supernova was installed on our Fujitsu PCs with Ubuntu 22.04. Internet works well, so does sending e-mails. Shutting down and booting again will help sometimes, but I also have to restart the router upstairs (Netgear) again from time to time. I checked all settings, closed Surfshark VPN, contacted our provider that checked the connections up to their modem / router in our home, everything was fine. Installing a new router did not change anything.

Of course when we reboot our machines and/or reset our router Thunderbird works fine again, but this is not a big pleasure..... I hope you still might have a tip!

With kind regards,

Ed

content:
Try with the recommended settings:

incoming IMAP: mail.twc.com, 995, SSL/TLS, normal password, User Name = email address

outgoing SMTP: mail.twc.com, 587, STARTTLS, normal password, User Name = email address

https://www.spectrum.net/support/internet/mobile-email-setup

content:
You are on Windows 10. Please

  • Start *Windows* in safe mode with networking enabled https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode
  • Still in Windows safe mode, start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot mode https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Does situation improve?

If no, check tools > activity manager for background activity. And check Tools > Developer > error console for errors.

content: Just a guess: the news server once didn't require a user id, but now does. Thunderbird sees this as an account and a request to get messages defaults to all accounts. If you no longer use the news server, my suggestion is to remove the account.
